div.p: Xin Liu*, Zicheng Chi*, Wei Wang, Yao Yao, and Ting Zhu University of Maryland, Baltimore County
Consume little energy Enable lots of IOT applications
MIMO Widely used More reliable and faster
Related work (MOXcatter [Mobisys18]) Reflect MIMO signals Conventional backscatter techniques
Leverage MIMO technique on backscatter tags Support space-time coding, spatial diversity, and generic design Dramatically decrease BER (862x) and increase throughput

C2: Demodulation How to deal with pre-scatter
C3: Extend to MK N How to support any number of antennas on sender, tag, and receiver

The MIMO backscatter contains three stages

Decode by using maximum likelihood estimation
Sender: A B210 USRP + 2 Antennas Receiver: Two X310 USRPs + 4 Antennas Tag: Low power FPGA + 4 Antennas
Real-world scenarios: 1. SIMO and MIMO 2. BER, PRR, and throughput 3. Sender-to-tag distance, tag-to-receiver distance, and sender-to-receiver distance 4. SNR, packet length, oscillator accuracy
BER is reduced by a factor of 862
P a c k e t
The throughput of VMscatter with four antennas is around 4 times as high as that of related work
Conclusion The first versatile MIMO backscatter system Address special design challenges A generic design Build a hardware platform Extensively evaluated under multiple real-world scenarios
